Below are excerpts from ''Spider's Poem'' by Cori Sherman:
Today I saw while sitting on my bed
A spider hanging above my head
He was hanging from a thread so bare
I could barely tell the thread was there
The spider's skin was very black
And I nearly had a heart attack.
I went screaming from my room
'Daddy, Daddy, I'll meet my doom!
If you don't catch that spider soon!''
I was making such a fuss
That my father came to see
And I showed him the little bug
That was scaring me.
My father simply smiled and tried to sit me on his lap
''No, daddy, no'' I said
''Why can't you give the spider one crushing little slap?''
My father looked at me and said with voice real deep
''Honey, listen to my story and do not make a peep.'
Spiders build a web where they live and eat all day
And what they eat is other bugs
That dare to come my way.
The spider will not hurt you
He makes the earth a better place
And I wish you could see his web
It's prettier than lace
You're bigger than the spider
And he's more scared than you
I will not slap this spider
Or crush him with my shoe.
If it weren't for these little guys
The world would have too many flies
So instead of killing the spider why not see him free
So he can build a web and we can let him be?
I looked at my dad with wonder
Because he made me see
That what I thought was scary
Was really good for me.
